ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia-Pac traded mixed as headwinds from DJIA's worst quarter on record were offset by a surprise expansion in Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI
content: Asia equity markets traded mixed with sentiment cautious after Wall St wrapped up the worst quarterly performance in the S&P 500 since 2008 and biggest quarterly loss on record for the DJIA, as risk appetite remained centred on the ongoing coronavirus pandemic in which the US, UK and Spain all experienced their highest daily death tolls to date. ASX 200 (+2.2%) and Nikkei 225 (-2.0%) were mixed with outperformance in Australia led by the energy sector after oil prices found mild reprieve overnight and as financials also benefitted from recent regulatory concessions, while the Japanese benchmark faltered on the weight of the detrimental currency flows and after negative Tankan numbers which showed the lowest reading in the Large Manufacturing Index in 7 years. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) diverged with the mainland underpinned by the surprise expansion in Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI and recent comments by China’s State Council which pledged further support measures including targeted RRR cuts. However, the mood in Hong Kong was less productive after a record slump in Retail Sales and with hefty losses seen in HSBC and Standard Chartered after they scrapped dividend and share repurchase plans on the directive of UK authorities to provide an extra cushion amid the coronavirus fallout. Finally, 10yr JGBs were slightly higher amid the negative risk appetite in Japan and after the BoJ recently raised the frequency of its purchase intentions for this month, although upside was capped by resistance ahead of 153.00 and due to a reserved Rinban operation in which the BoJ reduced its purchase amount for 3yr-5yr bonds.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia-Pac majors are somewhat mixed as headwinds from Wall St's worst quarter on record is offset by a surprise expansion in Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI
content:
Asia equity markets trade mixed with sentiment cautious following the headwinds from Wall St where stocks finished negative and wrapped up the worst quarterly performance in the S&P 500 since 2008 and biggest quarterly loss in the DJIA on record, as risk appetite remains centred on the ongoing coronavirus pandemic with US, UK and Spain all experiencing their highest daily death tolls to date. ASX 200 (+3.8%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.2%) are mixed with outperformance in Australia led by the energy sector after oil prices found mild reprieve overnight and as financials also benefit from recent regulatory concessions, while the Japanese benchmark falters on the weight of the detrimental currency flows and after negative Tankan numbers which showed the lowest reading in the Large Manufacturing Index in 7 years. Hang Seng (-0.5%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) are indecisive as the mainland benefits from better than expected Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI which showed a surprise expansion, as well as recent comments by China’s State Council which pledged further support measures including targeted RRR cuts. However, the mood in Hong Kong is less productive after a record slump in Retail Sales and with hefty losses seen in HSBC and Standard Chartered after they scrapped dividend and share repurchase plans on the directive of UK authorities to provide an extra cushion amid the coronavirus fallout.

In FX markets, the prior day’s retreat in the DXY was stemmed after finding support around the 99.00 level, which has resulted to a mild pullback in its peers across the pond with EUR/USD homing in on the 1.1000 level where there is a large EUR 1.9bln option expiry for today’s New York cut and with GBP/USD slipping below 1.2400, as well as nearby 20-Hour and 50-Hour MA levels. Elsewhere, USD/JPY attempts to nurse some of the recent losses but remains sub-108.00 and JPY-crosses are lacklustre amid the subdued risk-appetite in Japan, while antipodeans are lacklustre as both AUD/USD and NZD/USD consolidate near the prior day’s lows with better than expected Chinese PMI data, Australian Building Approvals and RBA minutes from the March emergency meeting doing little to spur price action as the latter provided very little in the way of fresh insight but suggested the likelihood of significant job losses ahead.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are slightly higher amid the negative risk appetite in Japan following a negative Tankan survey and after the BoJ also recently raised the frequency of its purchase intentions for this month, although prices are capped by resistance ahead of 153.00 and following a reserved Rinban announcement in which the BoJ reduced its purchase amount for 3yr-5yr bonds.

RBA Minutes from March 19th Emergency Meeting states members strongly supported proposed policy response as a comprehensive package and noted that focus of the program was on bond yields rather than quantity or timing of bond purchases
content:
Says:

  • Important to emphasise that the bank expected a recovery once the coronavirus outbreak is contained although timing is uncertain.
  • Bond markets had displayed signs of dysfunction.
  • There were likely to be significant job losses over the months ahead.
analysis_details: • As a reminder, the RBA lowered the  Cash Rate Target by 25bps to 0.25% and announced to buy government bonds in secondary market for the 1st time in history as speculated. Furthermore, the RBA announced to offer 3yr funding (TFF) to authorized deposit taking institutions with the facility valued at least AUD 90bln and adopted a target on 3yr government bond yield of around 0.25%, while it stated that banks will have access to additional low-cost funding if they expand lending to businesses.
